Zo calls his teacher to find out if he can ""stop by.""
""I'm great! I just wanted to make sure you were in your office so I can stop by for the homework; I'm going on my big trip tomorrow!""
To ""stop by"" is to visit someone for a short time. Zo wants to stop by his teacher's office-he wants to visit her for a short time so he can get the homework.
Here are more sentences that include the phrase
• ""Let's stop by the store on the way home.""
• ""Do you mind if I stop by after work?""

The Focus of This Lesson is Asking ""Who"" and ""Where"" and Answering Questions About Yourself.

who's the singer?""

we are going to cover a couple different ways to ask and answer questions in English. We'll begin with interrogative pronouns and move on to answering questions about yourself with negative and affirmative statements. Let's get started!

column1: Interrogative pronouns are the words used to ask questions. Here are the most commonly used interrogative pronouns:

Who - Who did the action?
What - What happened?
When - When did it happen? At what time?
Why - Why did it happen? What was the reason?
Where - Where did it take place?
How - How did it happen? How did it take place?

This group of interrogative pronouns is sometimes called
column2: ""the five Ws (and one H)"" because they all begin with the letter W (and the letter H).

column1: Using one of the ""five Ws"" is a great way to begin a conversation. Zo begins his conversation with Michelle by asking
column3:
who's the singer?""

After Michelle answers
column4: Zo then asks
column5:
""Where are you from?""

What else could Zo have asked Michelle?

Write five NEW questions using each of the ""five Ws (and one H)""

column1: More About Asking Where People are From!

How does Michelle know where Zo is from before he tells her? She probably hears his accent and recognizes it as being from South Africa. Michelle tests her knowledge by asking Zo if he is in fact from (country). Zo seems excited that Michelle correctly identifies where he is from
column2: even though she is wrong about the city.

column1: While doing so is considered rude in some countries
column2: it is not uncommon for Americans to ask foreign strangers where they are from. Usually it is a sign of genuine curiosity. As the years go by
column3: America and other countries in the western world are becoming more and more diverse
column4: and so is general interest in unfamiliar people and places. Granted
column5: not everyone has good feelings about the world becoming more international
column6: but if someone asks you where you're from
column7: you can be fairly sure that they want to get to know you better
column8: even if only for a short time.

column1: ""This is my business card. This is my e-mail address and this is my phone number. E-mail me!""
Possessive adjectives are words that are used with nouns to show ownership. In the dialogue
column3: ""This is my business card. This is my e-mail address and this is my phone number."" In this case
column4: the possessive pronoun is ""my
column5: which indicates that the nouns ""my"" modifies belong to the speaker; the business card
column7:
and phone number all belong to Zo.

The other possesive pronouns are:

column3: his
column4: her
column7: and their

column1:
My business card = the business card belonging to me
Your business card = the business card belonging to you
His business card = the business card belonging to him
Her business card = the business card belonging to her
Its business card = the business card belonging to it (a dog
column2:
perhaps? or a cat?)
Our business card = the business card belonging to us
Their business card = the business card belonging to them

column1: ""And"" is a coordinating conjunction used to link two words
column3: or clauses together.

""these"" refer to nouns that are nearby in time or space.

In the dialogue

and this is my phone number.""

He is showing his new friend Michelle his business card
column8:
which is nearby-- in his hand. On his business card are his email address and phone number. Often times a hand gesture like pointing is used with ""this"" and ""these"" to show just what it is the speaker is talking about.

column1: Informal imperatives are casual commands you can give/say to a friend or anyone else you feel close to. Commands are sentences used to tell someone to do something. Some examples of informal imperatives
column3:
are:

""E-mail me.""
""Call me.""
""Write me.""

In the dialogue
column4: Michelle says to Zo
column5: ""E-mail me!"" She is reuqesting that he e-mail her and now that they're friends
column6:
she uses an informal imperative.

Informal imperatives are created by using the present tense of a verb and adding an objective pronoun. Like this:

column1:
E-mail + me.
E-mail + him.
E-mail + her.
E-mail + us.
E-mail + them.

Call + me.
Call + him.
Call + her.
Call + us.
Cal + them.

Write + me.
Write + him.
Write + her.
Write + us
Write + them.

column2: you can make any of these informal imperatives into polite requests by adding ""please"":

column1:
Please mail me.
Please call me.
Please write me.

The most polite way to ask for someone's contact information—their phone number
column3: etc.—is to first offer your own. If the person is indeed interested in communicating with you further
column4: her or she will offer his or her contact information in return. If the person does NOT offer their information in return
column5: it is safe to assume that he or she is not interested in continuing a relationship with you. It's considered rude to demand that someone give you their personal information.

column1: Implied verbs are often used quick business transactions—when there isn't a lot of time for polite conversation

pronouns and phrases to other words in a sentence. Prepositions are everywhere! It's awfully difficult to get on without them. So don't try to! A preposition shows the relationship of its object to the rest of the sentence.

column1:
The sentences in the dialogue that use prepositions are (prepositions are underlined):

For two weeks.* = I'll stay in New York for two weeks.
At The L Hotel.* = I'm staying at The L Hotel.
I'm here on business and to sight see. = I'm here for the purpose of business and to do some sight seeing.
(*These sentences also include implied subjects and verbs for the reason mentioned above: both Zo and the customs official would like to keep their interaction as short as possible.)
Some of the most commonly used prepositions are

column3: ""across
column4: ""after
column7: ""around
column8: ""at

column1: Write five (5) sentences that each include one of the above prepositions.

I drink water throughout the day.
She ran after the bus.
The book is under your desk.
You'll notice that the customs official is very short with Zo—that is to say
column2: he or she doesn't provide long questions or answers. He or she simply wants to get the job done. He or she is not interested in friendly conversation
column3: hence the absence of polite requests and small talk. The customs official is a man or woman of very few words; he or she is all about business
column4: as we say. This seems to be true
column6: of customs officials all over the world. Their job of keeping the airports—and countries
column7: really—safe from intruders with bad intentions is a very serious one. If they were to be nice and polite and relaxed
column8: it's likely that criminals would take advantage of them
column9: and that the process of getting through customs would be much longer than it is. Customs officials have a high volume of visitors to process
column10: as well as anxious visitors who simply want to move through the line quickly and easily so they can claim their baggage and be on their way. It's understandble that customs officials would want to do their jobs as efficiently and as quickly as possible. Which means very few words! And very little—if any—conversation!

column1: ""To go"" is the infinitive of the verb

To + sleep = to sleep
To + walk = to walk
To + run = to run
To + study = to study
To + read = to read

column1:
""I'd like to go to Times Square.""

Zo (subject) + would like (verb) + to go (infinitive) + to Times Square (direct object).

""Or"" is a conjunction. You may remember from previous lessons that a conjunction is a word that links two words or phrases together. ""Or"" shows two choices or possibilities. For example:

column1: ""Do you prefer to sit here or there?""
""Would you like to eat inside or outside?""

column8: or transport
column9: people quickly between two locations. While standard buses make many stops along a route
column10: shuttle buses travel between two locations. Even though many feature extra room for luggage
column11: airport shuttle buses are usually much smaller than standard buses. The most well-known airport shuttle bus company in America is Supershuttle
column12: which serves air travelers across the country.

Demonstratives are adjectives and pronouns that identify which object or person the person speaking about. In this case
Demonstratives agree in number (singular or plural) with the objects or people being identified and change depending on how far they are from the speaker.

""What is that?"" = ""What is that thing (singular) over there?""

It's probably safe to say that there are convenience stores in every heavily populated corner of the world. But also that every country and every city has its own brand of convenience stores. In New York
column2: there are two main types of convenience stores: chains—or a series of stores owned by one big company—and independently owned
column3: smaller stores and street stalls.
because they're owned and operated by a big corporation
column4: have the largest and broadest selection of products. From sewing kits and gift wrap to magazines and cold medicine
column5: chain convenience stores have just about anything you might need for any given situation. Smaller
column7: because of their common location at or near street corners—and street stalls (sometimes called bodegas) take up far less space and so have fewer items to choose from
column8: most of which are foods and snacks
column9: and important household items like toilet paper
column11: and toothpaste. These smaller operations often sell sandwiches and other prepared foods
column12: and are often open until the late hours of the night.

column2: chains kept regular business hours and closed in the evening; these days
column3: to compete with the smaller convenience stores and street stalls
column4: which are open quite late
column5: more and more chains stay open either late into the evening

Interrogative sentences are questions. Basic statements can be made into questions very simply; just place the verb before the word ""there."" Here are some examples:

column1:
""There is Internet in the room."" = ""Is there Internet in the room?""
""There are toiletries."" = ""Are there toiletries?""

The Focus of This Lesson is Using the Future Simple Tense to Answer Formal Questions

We use the future simple tense to explain what we will do in the future. When we use ""will

column1: 2. Using the Infinitive Form of a Verb
The infinitive form of a verb is a verb with the word ""to"" in front of it. The verb that follows ""to"" is in its base form
column2: also known as its dictionary form. We can use infinitive verbs as the subject of a sentence and to follow other verbs.

column1: 3. Answering Questions in a Formal Situation
When answering questions in a formal situation
column2: we try to be as polite as possible. That usually means using a lot of words. In informal situations
column3: we can drop words and shorten sentences.

column2: the border officer asks Katrina where she will live and Katrina answers ""I will live in London.""

column1: She could have answered ""I'll live in London
column3: and it would have answered the question. However
column4: both sentences are more informal than the answer she gave
column5: and aren't suitable as formal answers.

column1: Another example is her answer ""I am here to study."" She could have answered ""I'm studying here
column3: but they wouldn't be good answers to a formal question.

column1: If you asked a question in formal English
column2: always try to reply in formal English.

column1: Here are a few common words and phrases that are used in formal English
Although English doesn't have the strict rules of some other languages
column2: it still has formal and informal ways of speaking. Formal English isn't as distinctly different from informal English as other languages either
column3: but there is a difference. Speaking informally when formal language is expected won't impress the people you are talking to. If you're able to switch between formal and informal language depending on the situation
column4: your English will sound more natural and fluent than if you can't. When you're in a formal situation
column5: it's always best to use a full sentence instead of just one- or two-word answers
column6: and to not use any slang or colloquialisms you may have picked up from English TV programmes or friends. If you're talking to strangers
column7: people in authority
column8: or are in a situation such as a job interview
column10: if the situation becomes more relaxed and they speak informally to you
column11: then you can speak informally as well. If in doubt though

The UK used to have many small grocery shops throughout the country where people did their weekly shopping
column2: but these have become less popular as more large supermarkets have opened. The supermarkets use their size and buying power to sell goods more cheaply. There are four big supermarket chains that own the majority of the market: Tesco
column3: ASDA
column4: Sainsbury's
column5: and Morrisons. Some supermarkets are in easy-to-reach locations in the centre of towns and villages
column6: but some of the bigger supermarkets are on the outskirts and need a car or bus ride to reach. British people usually shop big
column7: and often buy enough food to last a week or two at a time. Meat and vegetables are popular foods to buy for people who cook at home
column8: as most traditional British food is based around them. Other foods such as rice and pasta are eaten
column9: but are less popular than in other countries. Most supermarkets also do a wide range of frozen meals that are quick and easy to prepare by simply microwaving them. These 'ready meals' are becoming increasingly popular.

Giving directions in the UK isn't the easiest thing to do. Cities and towns are not neatly laid out in blocks
column2: but have roads that twist and turn and go in all directions. For longer distances there are many convenient and well looked-after motorways and major roads
column3: but navigating around cities can be tricky. Although road names are usually well signposted and easy to spot
column4: most people in the UK give directions using landmarks
column6: or use traffic lights and islands. There are usually several different ways to get somewhere and the shortest route isn't always the quickest as it depends on traffic and the time of day. There are many ways to give directions and it is very easy to get lost. Sat navs have become very popular in recent years!

1. Using Adverbs of Frequency and Prepositions of Time

to describe our schedule.

Although education in the UK varies slightly from country to country
column2: children have to be in full-time education from the ages of 5 to 16. From the ages of 5 to 11
column3: they attend primary school and then spend five years at secondary school. Many children decide to have further education from the ages of 16 to 18
column4: but this is their choice. Usually
column5: school is Monday to Friday and runs from around 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. There are after-school activities and clubs
column6: but they are not compulsory. Unlike other countries
column7: students do not graduate from secondary school. Instead
column8: students sit several exams
column10: and get a mark for each subject. There are also national exams at the age of 11 and other exams created by the teachers in other years.

The Focus of This Lesson is Discussing the Weather

1. Using Adjectives to Describe the Weather
An adjective is a word that is used to describe or modify a noun or pronoun. When talking about the weather

column3: because they are based on weather nouns!

column1: I can't see the stars because of the cloud.
The sky is too cloudy to see the stars.
We can describe the weather in more detail by using weather phrases.

column2: we can say that it is ""boiling hot."" Or
column3: if it's very cold we can say that it is ""freezing cold.""

The windows were being rattled by a weak wind.
We use the present continuous tense to describe something that is

column1: Present continuous sentences are formed like this:

column4: but it isn't cold. In Liverpool it is raining lightly and in Manchester it is raining heavily. In Inverness it is snowing. My friend lives in the north of Scotland and he isn't driving to work today. I suggest that everyone stays at home!""

The UK's climate is pretty mild as winter temperatures are cool

The Focus of This Lesson is Asking for Advice and Suggestions

1.  Use modal verbs to ask for and give suggestions
1. Using Modal Verbs To Ask For and Give Suggestions
A modal verb is an auxiliary verb that describes modality—the potential of something happening
column2: the ability for it to happen
column3: and whether there is permission for it to happen.

column1: An example from the dialogue is when Katrina says ""You should have a party.""
Modal verbs are generally followed by the base form of the verb.
1.     ""She should come with us to the party.""
•     ""They must finish their homework before dinner.""

column2: modal verbs' grammar dictates that modal verbs are followed by the base form of the verb to the present or future moment. However
column3: modal verbs can also be used with other forms of verbs. The most common of these modal verbs' grammar forms is the use of the modal plus a perfect form to refer to a past time when using a modal verb of probability.

column1: •     ""Jane could have thought he was late.""
Other forms used include the modal plus the progressive form to refer to what may/should/could be happening at the present moment of time.
1.     ""He may be studying for his math exam.""
•     ""He must be thinking about the future.""
Here are some examples of modal verbs in action.
A conditional sentence is a sentence that says that something will happen
column2: but only if a condition is fulfilled. An example from the dialogue is ""The new Chinese restaurant has discounts if you go on Thursdays."" These sentences use the conjunction ""if.""

column1: There are three types of conditional ""if"" sentences.
Type 1: it is possible and very likely that the condition will happen
We make these sentences using [if] + [simple present] + [will verb]
Type 2: it is possible but unlikely that the condition will happen.
We make these sentences using [if] + [simple past] + [would infinitive]

column2: I would go to the gym.""

column1: Type 3: it is impossible for the condition to occur because it is in the past.

column3: past participle]

column2: I would have gone to the gym.""

There are many reasons to celebrate in the UK. The most popular reasons for parties and celebrations are birthdays and weddings. Important birthdays
column2: such as 18 and any year after 20 that ends in 0 are especially celebrated. People may also have celebrations for landmark wedding anniversaries such as 25 or 50. You might get invited to smaller celebrations too
column3: such as for a pregnancy
column4: leaving a job
column6: or moving house. Large parties are usually held at a special place such as a hotel
column7: event room at a pub
column8: or a church or public hall. Small celebrations can be held at home or at a restaurant. For bigger parties such as weddings and birthdays you might receive a paper invitation. This will have the details of the party
column9: including location and time. It is polite to send a reply saying if you will go or not. For smaller celebrations
column10: you might just get asked during a conversation.

A conjunction is a word that connects words
column3: or sentences. There are two types of conjunctions.
""or
column4: ""nor
column7: ""so."" They are all short words so they are easy to remember! They are used to connect words and clauses of equal importance. The most common of these are ""and

column1: These are used to link subordinate clauses to main clauses. The conjunction ""as"" is a subordinate clause. We use it to give a reason so it is very similar to ""because.""

3. Using the Imperative Form to Give Reminders and Recommendations
In lesson 4 we spoke about the imperative form. This is used to give direct commands
column2: such as ""shut the door"" and ""be quiet.""

column1: We can also use the imperative form to give reminders and recommendations.
•        ""Don't forget"": ""Don't forget your umbrella.""; ""Don't forget to brush your teeth.""

Bikes aren't as popular a mode of transport in the UK compared to other countries. The UK is lacking in bike paths and many roads are busy and congested
column2: so it is dangerous to ride a bike. The UK also has many hills
column3: so it can be difficult to ride a bike too far! There aren't many places to safely park a bike either. Most people prefer to drive a car or use public transport
column4: such as buses and trains
column5: to get to their destination. For those that do ride a bike
column6: there are many laws. Bikes should be ridden on the road
column7: not on the pavement
column8: and it is the law for cyclists to wear helmets. These laws and the extra energy and time needed to cycle are a great deterrent for many people.

The Focus of This Lesson is Discussing and Assessing our Own Ability
""Oh
1. Use modal verbs to talk about our abilities
1. Using Modal Verbs to Talk About our Abilities
We have spoken about modal verbs in previous lessons and focused on using them to give permission in lesson 8. In this lesson we will look at another use for them-to talk about ability.
We can use the modal verb ""can"" to express ability. Another form that can be used to express ability is ""to be able to."" Usually
column2: either of these two forms can be used.

column1: 1.     ""I can play the piano."" = I'm able to play the piano.
•     ""She can speak Spanish."" = She's able to speak Spanish.
There is no future or perfect form of ""can."" We can use 'to be able to' in both future and perfect tenses.
1.     ""Jack's been able to play golf for three years.""
•     ""I'll be able to speak Spanish when I finish the course.""
The verbs ""can"" and ""to be able"" have the same meaning; both are used to express an ability or possibility.
1.     ""I can sing"" = I am able to sing
•     ""I can dance"" = I am able to dance
•     ""I can write"" = I am able to write
•     ""He or she can"" = He or she is able
If we want to talk about abilities we don't have
column2: then we take ""can"" and ""to be able to"" and use their negative forms.

column1: I am not able to play piano.
•     ""She's able to speak Spanish."" - She isn't able to speak Spanish.
Although both ""can't"" and ""not able to"" mean the same thing and are interchangeable
column2: using ""can't"" is more common and popular.

column1: We can also ask and answer simple questions using these words. Again
column2: although ""be able to"" is fine to use
column3: ""can"" is more popular.

column1: We can answer all of these questions with either ""Yes
column3: I can't.""

column2: both Katrina and Phil talk about what they can and can't do.

column1: I wonder what sport they both can do?
Adverbs of frequency are words that explain how often something happens.
There are two types of frequency adverbs.
These are adverbs that are a definite time period. Examples are daily
column3: hourly
column4: monthly
column7: every year
column8: every day etc.

column1: These are adverbs that aren't a definite time period.

column3: are...

column1: I always brush my teeth in the morning.
He always shouts at me if I'm late.
She usually waits for me at the train station.
Tag questions are a structure in which a declarative statement or an imperative is turned into a question by adding an interrogative fragment. We call these fragments a ""tag.""
""You can still try + right"" = ""You can still try
Tag questions are used to confirm information
Tag questions are more prevalent in spoken than in written English. They can be used to express a variety of emotions
column2: such as politeness or lack of confidence
column3: while others are used to express anger or suspicion. Tag questions are also often used to show emphasis. So
column4: there are several ways to ""tag"" questions.

Joining a gym is becoming increasingly popular in the UK
column2: especially with young adults and professionals. Most cities and large towns have several gyms for people to choose from and they often open 24 hours a day. Gyms are a great place to do your own exercise or to enrol in classes or have training programs planned for you. As well as gyms
column3: some people like to go walking or running and many pubs and social clubs have sports teams. Football is especially popular with pubs
column4: and many people spend their weekends playing football games in amateur leagues. There is also a big diet culture in the UK and there are many specialist diet foods that can be bought both in regular supermarkets and also health food stores. These health stores can also be found in most cities and shopping centres.

The Focus of This Lesson is Accepting or Rejecting an Invitation in a Polite Manner
""Thanks for the kind invite! I'd love to come!""
1. Form the present continuous tense (with the verb: having)
Accepting or rejecting invitations in a polite manner
1. Forming the Present Continuous Tense (with the verb ""having"")
In lesson 6 we introduced the present continuous tense. We use this tense to describe something that is
column3: happening right now.

column1: An important verb that can be used to make many present continuous sentences is the verb ""to have
column2: which is ""having"" in the present continuous form. We can use having with many nouns to make present continuous sentences.
Daniel says ""I'm having a housewarming party tomorrow evening.""
having is used in place of the verbs ""eating"" and ""drinking."" This sounds very natural and casual.

column1: Auxiliary verbs are sometimes called ""helping verbs"" as they add meaning or functionality to other verbs. They are used to make questions
column3: exclamations and to help with the different verb tenses.

column2: let's look at how ""be"" conjugates. It is different depending on who the subject of the sentence is.

column1: 1.     ""I have been here for a week.""
•     ""You have been here for a week.""
•     ""She has been here for a week.""
•     ""They have been here for a week.""
1.     ""I had been sick for three days.""
•     ""You had been sick for three days.""
•     ""He had been sick for three days.""
•    ""We had been sick for three days.""
1.     ""I will have been studying English for 6 years by the time I go to university.""
•     ""You will have been studying English for 6 years by the time you go to university.""
•     ""She will have been studying English for 6 years by the time she goes to university.""
•     ""We will have been studying English for 6 years by the time we go to university.""
3. Accepting or Rejecting Invitations in a Polite Manner
It's very likely that you will receive invitations from friends or colleagues to go out
column3: see a film together
column4: or many other activities. You may even be invited to more formal occasions

column1: When it is an informal invitation between friends
column2: you can respond in many informal ways
column3: but with these formal invitations
column4: you should also reply in a formal and polite way.

column1: Whether you are accepting or rejecting
column2: it is polite to first thank the person with a phrase such as ""Thank you for inviting me.""
you can use phrases such as:
sometimes an explanation as to why you are rejecting is needed. When you give a reason
column3: be polite! It is not polite to say that you don't want to
column4: even if that is the truth.

column1: To reject an invitation you can use phrases such as:

column2: but I'm sorry that I can't attend.""
but I am busy that evening.""
but I already have other plans.""

column1: Saying that you are busy is a safe way to reject an invitation.
""Thanks for the kind invite! I'd love to come!""

Although people tend to buy their own houses and settle into a home for several years
column2: moving house is still something that happens quite frequently. It can be a very stressful time if buying a house
column3: as the sale can fall apart quite easily
column4: especially if you're in a chain and are relying on other people to move out before you can move in. After moving house
column5: it is polite to introduce yourself to your neighbours. This isn't a formal meeting and you don't need to buy gifts like in some other countries and cultures. In recent times
column6: people generally just go to their next-door neighbours' houses or even just wait until they see them in the street. An easy way to greet the neighbours is to invite them to a housewarming party. You don't have to invite the neighbours and could just invite your own existing friends
column7: but if you're going to have a party shortly after moving it
column8: it's polite to warn your neighbours first!
